subject: News Summary
body:
CBSNews.com






April 19, 2007

TOP STORIESA Time To Mourn
Virginia Tech has turned away from gruesome video images of mass killer Cho Seung-Hui to mourn the victims of his shooting
                        rampage.
                         More...Watch: Picture Worth A Thousand Words
• Gonzales Defends Prosecutor Firings
                     					| Watch• Gates In Iraq: Patience Running Out
                     					| Watch• Va. Tech Killer Picked On, Classmates Say
                     					| WatchU.S.Va. Tech Killer Picked On, Classmates Say
Former classmates say that long before he snapped, Virginia Tech gunman Cho Seung-Hui was picked on, pushed around and laughed
                        at over his shyness and the strange way he talked when he was a schoolboy in the Washington suburbs. More...Watch: Package Of 'Marginal Value'
• New Hampshire Set To OK Civil Unions• A Time To Mourn
                     					| Watch• Oklahoma City Marks Bombing Anniversary
                     					| Watch• More StoriesWorldAnti-Castro Militant Leaves U.S. Jail
Anti-Castro Cuban militant Luis Posada Carriles has been released from federal custody and is en route to his wife's house
                        in Miami, his lawyer said. More...
• Palestinian Leader: BBC Reporter Is Alive• Gates In Iraq: Patience Running Out
                     					| Watch• Report: Children In Darfur Tortured, Raped• More StoriesPoliticsGonzales Defends Prosecutor Firings
Fighting for his job, Attorney General Alberto Gonzales told a skeptical Senate panel he played only a limited role in the
                        firing of eight federal prosecutors. Gonzales insisted the dismissals were "justified."   More...Watch: Sen. Leahy: Tell The Truth
• Ex-N.J. Gov. McGreevey Now Teaches Ethics• N.J. Gov. Corzine Still Needs Ventilator• Wolfowitz To Offer Changes At World Bank• More StoriesHealth132M Flu Vaccine Doses Expected For Fall
Flu vaccine manufacturers expect to have a record 132 million doses ready for the 2007-2008 flu season. Officials say even
                        more could be available if a fifth company joins the manufacturers' ranks. More...
• New Pet Food Worry: Contaminated Rice
                     					| Watch• Hormone Use Linked To Higher Cancer Risk
                     					| Watch• Vaccine May Help Fight Breast Cancer
                     					| Watch• More StoriesSciTechDead Whale Retrieved From Brooklyn Bay 
It took two attempts, but a baby whale that died in a small Brooklyn bay after swimming aimlessly in its waters for two days
                        was pulled out with the help of two police divers. More...
• Could Global Warming Cause War?
                     					| Watch• MySpace Enters Online News Business• Report: Cars Still Beat SUVs In Safety
                     					| Watch• More StoriesBusinessReport: Cars Still Beat SUVs In Safety
When comparing the death rates in passenger vehicles with similar weight, cars are still safer than SUVs and pickup trucks.
                        But the insurance industry finds that SUVs and pickups are catching up with cars, due to electronic stability control.  More...Watch: Report: Cars Safer Than SUVs
• Keeping Your Safe-Deposit Box Safe• MySpace Enters Online News Business• BlackBerry Outage Leaves Thumbs Idle• More StoriesEntertainment"American Idol" Says So Long, Sanjaya!
The reality show's unlikely star was finally voted off the show this week. More...Watch: Simon Cowell Gets Judged
• Rock Asks Court To Weigh Paternity Claim• Lindsay Lohan: I'm Not An Addict• Trump Slings Panties At Walters• More StoriesOpinionGuns And Abortions
CBSNews.com's Dick Meyer says those two newly-reignited arguments won't be resolved anytime soon. "We aren't polarized,
                        we are pluralized," Meyer says. More...
• The World Turned Upside Down
                     					| Watch• A Hard-Won Victory For Life
                     					| Watch• Chipping Away At Roe v. Wade
                     					| Watch• More StoriesCBS NEWS BROADCASTSThe Early Show: Classmates: Cho Saved His Words For Videos
Virginia Tech students that knew Cho Seung-Hui say that he was quiet and odd. They knew he had troubles, but never expected
                        to hear the terrible words that he spewed in videos sent to NBC News. More...Watch: Students Describe Shooter

Professor: 'I Knew It Was Him'In a visit to Bradley University, poet Nikki Giovanni, Cho Seung-Hui's former professor, became emotional when talking about
                                    the tragedy on the Virginia Tech campus. WBBM's Suzanne Le Mignot reports.
